Remnant 2 is the kind of game that makes you lose track of time. It’s tough, unpredictable, and sometimes frustrating, but every bit of struggle pays off once you get into the rhythm.

On PC the gunplay feels tight and satisfying. Every shot has weight and every dodge matters. I played mostly Hunter with a touch of Gunslinger and that setup felt perfect to me. The balance between precision and speed kept every fight exciting. The Merciless became my absolute favorite weapon. The way it looks, sounds, and hits never gets old.

The campaign is an experience from start to finish. Every world feels alive in its own strange and haunting way. The atmosphere tells the story more than the dialogue does, and it works. You can feel the history and the loss in every corner.

The boss rushes were my favorite part. They push you to your limits and make every victory feel earned. Beating a boss after several tries feels like a real accomplishment.

There are some frustrating parts. The difficulty can spike without warning and the random elements sometimes make progress slower than it needs to be. But those rough moments make the wins that much sweeter.

Remnant 2 mixes tension, chaos, and satisfaction in a way few games do. It challenges you to stay calm under pressure and rewards you for sticking with it.

If you like games that test you but make every success feel meaningful, Remnant 2 is an easy recommendation.

I got this game as a Christmas gift from a friend of mine back in 2023, and despite some nitpicks or frustrations, Remnant 2 has become one of my favorite games in recent years.
I'll admit, this review has been a long time coming.

Now, I'm not too familiar with Souls-likes as this and the previous game are my main introduction, but it's a seamless blend of TPS, Action RPG, Rougelite and of course, Souls-like. The main source of replayability comes from re-rolling either the campaign or adventure mode (With boss rush on the side since the Dark Horizon update) as many events are randomized on each world. Admittedly, this does run the risk of getting repetitive (or annoying if you're trying to roll a certain dungeon or event), but the gameplay loop is too much fun for me to get too bored.
  Another element I love is the variety weapons and weapon mods available, the game takes it's premise of traveling across various, radically different worlds to give you stuff like a gun that spams lightning and leaves electric stakes or a discus thrower that bounces off targets, or you have mods you attach to more "normal" guns like corrosive rounds or deploy space bugs to harass enemies. Combine this with the flexible Archetype system for setting up your class, different relics, hundreds of rings and amulets (You'll have a jewelry store's inventory sooner or later) and mutators you can equip onto your weapons... if you love trying out different character builds, be they optimal or unorthodox, you're in for a treat.
  Remember too, that if an item (say a ring for example) doesn't seem useful, setting it up with other items to synergize can make certain "Gimmicky" items viable options. 

One also can't talk about this game without making mention of the bosses, because honestly, the worst I have to say about some of them is "Heh, it was alright" as most of them, between the presentation, the music and the challenge are top-tier. I also have to point out that even if I had to lower many graphical settings to run this game, it still looks amazing and I love how different each world is, even if I get lost here and there.

Regarding the story, the gist is that twenty years have passed since the last game and the Root, the main villians' of the series have lost their chokehold on earth, allowing the human race to begin rebuilding. However the rest of the universe is still at risk, thus what begins as a simple misadventure becomes a quest to save the worlds from annihilation, leading you to navigate the blighted jungles of Yaesha, the grim Victorian style streets and extravagant Fae palaces of Lossom and the haunting desolation of N'Erud. So, right away I'm just gonna say that the story isn't anything to write home about, they put more effort into it than in the last game, but gameplay comes first and foremost here. Despite that however, I did find myself remembering various characters you encounter (Maybe re-rolling had something to do with that) and I do enjoy the little touch of your character having a voice, blank slate for the player they may be.
  Now while the story itself may not win an award anytime soon, there is tons of lore snippets you can find, mostly by inspecting items you find or the rare journal left behind or by talking with the characters you run across. As an Elder Scrolls fanboy, I love reading lore and gobbled up any scrap of information I could on this setting.

In terms of critiques for the game, I do admit there are a few. The chief one I think that comes to mind is some of the puzzles. I have nothing against puzzles but I must warn you, in your quest to find Archetypes, armor sets or weapons there are a few that are far from simple and some things folks only learned thanks to datamining. The good news is if your stuck, a web search will help as many players have shared their findings over the years. Another nitpick which may boil down to preference is that armor no longer gives special bonuses (beyond defensive values) like they did in the first game. I get it, the archetypes and the recent prism system fill that void but I can see people viewing it as a downgrade. Another thing to note is that while I love the combat and the different worlds, when traveling through most dungeons and general biomes, you're bound to fight LOTS of the same enemy over and over, which some may find repetitive. It's ironic really, so much variety but they'll spam the same dude in mass depending on the locale.

However, these nitpicks are just that, nitpicks. Remnant 2 is an amazing game and one I recommend, both for solo and co-op. I do admit, co-op isn't something I did much of, but man oh man was it fun! My only regret was that I didn't do more of it.
This game has been wonderful, I even got all the achievements and finished a hardcore run! But I believe it's time for this Traveler to put his guns down, let the ashes settle and rest.

This game is better in just about every way over the first Remnant. Weapons feel better, the story starts out promising, the class system is straight up better with greater depth, and the build variety is just as great, if not better. It really feels like a AA game with a solid budget behind it. Boss quality is generally good even if it is fairly easy outside of a few. Graphically, with it being one of the first UE5 titles, it's actually well-made from a technical perspective, even if it can be lacking in color in the base game.

As for issues, there are a few to point out. The game is much better with friends as playing solo, particularly in the dlc, the enemy ganks that the game can throw at you can be tedious at times. You walk into a room and 5-6 enemies can sometimes attack and so certain classes that give a free revive almost seems needed just to reduce the tediousness of the game design. Traversal, just like the first game, is still an issue. It feels like the areas are too large with not enough to do in them. General enemy design isn’t too engaging as you can kill most enemies without them even getting close to you so ganks are needed to give challenge. The 'Detailed Shadows' graphical setting produces stutter when pressing start or opening the map so keep it off (tested on Radeon 9070 XT gpu and 9800X3D cpu). The story itself, much like the first Remnant, isn't very good but in 2, it takes itself more seriously with more of it and as a result, falls flat hard by the end. 

The dlc is solid but it’s more of the same. The Awakening King is generally good all around as I found it had the most interesting story, solid level design, and an interesting concept from a lore perspective. The Forgotten Kingdom is rough and is by far my least favorite due to the final boss and story but it does have nice visuals. The Dark Horizon has a great final boss and solid story for that world but I found the level design to be frustrating to explore. 

Overall, it’s a good soulslike and I enjoyed it but struggled to finish it due to the dlc. Buy when on sale and I highly recommend to play with friends as the game is much better with friends than solo. Also, don’t enable ‘Detailed Shadows’ as this created stutter every single time I opened the menu or map. 7.5/10.

Remnant II thrives the most when it embraces its randomized campaign, but suffers when it hides swathes of its content behind obtuse puzzle design and random chance. This makes it extremely satisfying and worthwhile to play through several times, but an absolute nightmare to 100% complete. 

Remnant II tells a patchwork story of three worlds and their struggles against an eldritch evil, The Root. For those unfamiliar with Remnant 1's unique approach to storytelling, this story is composed of randomized maps, encounters, enemies, and story choices. Each world has three unique, but interconnected stories to be told, and hundreds of encounters and loot to find. This can be a bit confusing for first time players, and some storylines have significantly stronger writing and storytelling techniques than others. 

Some more positives: gunplay is varied, with some really unique and satisfying guns (or bows) to use. Active skills, passive abilities, and weapon mods are varied and impactful, opening up for lots of cool archetypes. Rings and amulets could have used some creative love, but they did their job of opening up more build options. The music is great, the world design is impactful, and the environments are huge and beautiful.

There's a slew of negatives that prevent Remnant from reaching its full potential. The puzzle design (if you can call if that) is poor, usually with no indication that a puzzle is even present. Developers fully intended on players data-mining solutions, and rerolling campaigns over and over again until they get the correct set of events for rare and powerful items. Some of the randomized events are poorly done, locking you out of rewards unless you reroll the ENTIRE game again. You cannot change difficulty during a campaign, so if you started and it's too easy, you just have to suck it up until your next playthrough. Level scaling is poorly thought out, where enemies scale with you. This means upgrading your weapon often makes your enemies deal more damage and take less. 

Player-character voice acting is really rough, with some really cringey voice lines. Audio logs are poorly done, forcing you to stand next to them doing nothing in order to listen. There's an audio bug in the final area that kills your ears, kind of ruining the climax of the narrative. Menu navigation is slow, especially when attempting to fast travel or use checkpoints.

It's a 50:50 review, honestly. My main issue is ... why does this even exist? It doesn't really do anything better than Remnant 1. Yet it is a quite expensive undertaking, and the DLCs can actually make the initial campaign A LOT harder if you happen to roll them. Why? Because for some reason the devs decided that each campaign would be randomized. More on that later.

The good stuff out of the way:
- It's not ugly (but also not super impressive)
- The worlds are different both in optics and in layout
- Decent enemy variety
- The 2-class system is neat, sort of, but nothing new in this genre


Now for all the stuff I didn't really like:

- Each world has 2 different "chapters" (3 with the addition of the DLC), yet the campaign chooses one at random, breaking up their individual stories. Not that it matters much, because those stories aren't all that interesting, for the most part, but it just is a bit strange to basically defeat the "final boss" before you even get to actually experience the story of that particular world. And like I said above, stumbling upon a DLC campaign (IF that is possible and they're not excluded from the pool) would mean stumbling upon more powerful enemies and bosses.
- The story itself is forgettable and skippable, I wish there were an option to just ... not have to click through endless dialogue. If the devs don't care about the story, why should I?
- Tutorial with a forced companion, who you will probably never interact with again in the future. Nice.
- Weapon variety is ... not all that impressive. You have "Long Guns" and "Handguns" and "Melee". The latter is completely forgettable in this game, unless you specifically build your character around that ... and even then, most bosses are not melee friendly at all. And unfortunately, you can't simply pick and choose which weapons you want to use, no you HAVE to use a small gun and a big gun, no way to just pick a sniper rifle and an AR, not that there are many sniper weapons to begin with. Most single shot weapons feel underpowered to me. You will not use them in boss fights, I imagine. They're just there to pick off far-away targets with headshots, yet if you have no viable alternative weapon or you just wanted to use another "long gun" you're shit out of luck.
- Weapon mods are similar. Some are neat, others feel pointless, and yet they all cost a lot to craft before you know it. Then you get actual good weapons and you can't use them anymore, since those all have UNIQUE weapon mods!!! I shit you not, I have like 20 weapons (including the garbage rusted ones you get from the beginning) and I can maybe install mods in only a few of them. I guess the game wants you to buy the other classes' weapons for variety, and they're probably even competitive if you upgrade them, so there's no real power imbalance I could see, but it just felt a bit disappointing.
- The trait system seems somehow worse than I remember it from Remnant 1, at least I didn't really feel compelled to invest in any of them ... More HP and Stamina are a given ... but it just doesn't feel rewarding to get 1% damage reduction, up to 10% ... it feels like an outdated mechanic.
- The main draw here is not the campaign, but rerolling the maps endlessly in adventure mode to find all the different stuff. Luckily, there is a 3rd party tool out there that actually let's you see what you rolled before you spend 5 hours in a world that has nothing you need. Not really sure about this design.
- Solo play basically forces you to be very defensive. The Handler class is a given, because the pet's healing and resurrection is almost mandatory, even on the easiest difficulty the enemies and bosses can hit like absolute units and soak a lot of damage. And then I got the Warden and focussed on shielding, which also saved my bacon more than once.
- Gameplay loop is rather boring. Once you've seen everything there's not a lot of incentive to keep playing for playing's sake. It's a rather mediocre 3rd person shooter. You walk/run, you shoot, you dodge. There is literally nothing more to it. You get 2 abilities and your weapons' abilities, so 4 to 5 in total, if you want to count the melee weapon, which you probably shouldn't. The character abilities are on a timer, mostly, and the weapon mods need to be charged by shooting ... The view is very restrictive, the dodge, even a normal dodge, very slow, meaning you often get caught in the follow-up attack anyway if you manage to dodge anything while aiming down sights. The bosses are a damage race, healing with your "estus flask" (the heart) takes forever and every hit staggers you out of the animation. I didn't find it particularly enjoyable, I'm afraid. There are better games of each genre out there. This is probably more fun if you play it with friends (not randoms, I can't see how THAT would be enjoyable with everyone rushing through the maps and doing whatever the fuck they want).
- There are supposedly armor sets in the game. I found ... two. In almost 30 hours. Yes, again, you can buy the starting armor of each class, but still ... that's not the same as finding stuff.
- Exploration is mid as well, it's trying to be "soulsy", but completely misses the mark here. It's more annoying than anything. Heck, the game might be better by just being a corridor or arena shooter ... and that's saying something.
- That annoying dog yowling and barking all the time.
- Bosses are mostly just spam and dodge fests ... hard to see anything.
- Instant death trap dungeons like in Super Fucking Meatboy ... in my 3rd person shooter (NO idea how to actually complete these).
- Puzzle rooms in my 3rd person shooter.

All in all, maybe get this on sale if you have 1 to 3 friends and you want some 3rd party shooting action. More characters can actually mean more character personalization. A lot more options to mess around with. Otherwise, I'd actually skip this one if you're in it just for the solo experience. I got it via Humble, bought the DLC for cheap, got my money's worth from it, but I'm not ... elated. Will finish the remaining 2 Losomn maps, because "sunk cost fallacy" ... and that's it.

I have waited AWHILE for this review. I love R1, recently started a new playthrough with some mods, remembering why I love the series, come back to R2. It, in theory, adds lots of new content, and yet, when I sit down to try this game again it feels like I'm met with endless little annoying bugs, performance issues and game play that feels like it went through so much QA on being balanced it's bland with very little fun or life to the game play. The first time I played the game and it should have felt new the game had abhorrent issues that made certain maps unplayable, so my initial memories of the game are negative. As time has gone on my issues changed. Got a better PC plus they optimized so now I can play normally, they also proceeded to nerf anything remotely fun and focused on making the game seem like it was made for hardcore players only. Then they started adding infinate ammo necklaces and things that give you lots of bulwark stacks making it seem like they were backtracking on the hardcore stance. Then they started doing the most ANNOYING modifiers to red enemies and bosses. Trapper; now that we've made a game all about dodging attacks, let's randomly penalize players for playing the way we have conditioned them to play. Hexer; what if the boss was constantly attacking in every direction with all status effects all at once on top of their normal move set? These just feel like pulling teeth and with the wrong combination of boss plus modifer the enemies feel so cheaty like I'm running Remnant from Hell or something. 

It just doesn't feel to me like the devs made a fun game with varied challenges. It's like they made a bunch of specific builds internally found that these builds crushed certain challenges then made specific things to counter all of them and now have flooded the game with the nonsense. Everything is sanded down and anything that they for some reason didn't think out and the players started swarming around they came out the gate with the nerf hammer like this is LoL, Dota or some other super competitive game. This is like if DS1 nerfed magic because it was op. It's op because people that suck at dodging need a build. I enjoy hitting my head against a brick wall in a souls like game, but when the brick wall grows spikes as I hit my head against it poking out my eye so I move to a different spot and it stabs me in the gut before I can hit my head, it's just frustrating. 

Then there is character building. In a vacume this games character building is ok. Comparing it to R1, it sucks. R1 you get 2 weapon mod slots, no mutator and no class skills, and yet, when I sat down and played it, I very quickly found myself having fun and feeling like I had a solid arrsenal. Everything in this game feels... muted. Sure they added Classes with a class skill, but half the class skills are weapon mods from the first game, so instead of any character using these skills now they are locked into one specific character with a specific play style. They gutted and destroyed all the defense mods from the first game or didn't add them at all, RIP flicker cloak. Now only specific classes can be defensive and only in the ways the devs want you to. On top of this as your power rating increases the game gets harder... not you getting stronger, and unlike the first game where you had 100% control over your power rating, the devs have once again decided to take this out of player hands. Your classes level up and contribute to your passive "power rating", where as before it would be entirely when you chose to upgrade your gear. This system sucks because upgrading yourself if actually detrimental, but then removing the ability to control this from players feels terrible. Sure a lot of games work that way, but I didn't like Remnant because it was "just another one of those games" I like it because it had it's own feeling to play. 

As you can see from time played I've given this game so many chances to suprise me and really tried to come at it with new eyes. Now, years after release, I'm still finding some of the same bugs that were a little annoying when I first picked it up, all the builds feel like they have to be in the boxes the devs want them and just over all lacking some kind of heart and soul the first had. Thought the game would be better this time around, after starting to play 2 years after I bought this with a friend this time. We beat the story campaign and decided to try to get all achievements after beating the first game. This game fixed a lot of problems the old one had while making new ones that are horrible changes. 

STORY: The people in the story besides a select few have no bearing on anything in the game and are just there to serve as random people to talk to, or as merchants. Everything in the story does not matter except for the old man being older, and the magic storyline plot point woman doing her magic storyline points for about 3 parts in the game. I never got any real excitement from talking to any person outside of bosses.

EQUIPMENT: Variety is very good. The guns have lots of different choices and a lot of them feel good to shoot. The rings are a hot mess where I have to sort them using filters because I have about 50 of them and I use maybe 15. Necklaces are powerful and I enjoy finding a new one. Armor is mostly just for looks compared to the first one, with heavy armor reducing marginally more damage. Mods are distinct and fun to use. Mutators are also a nice touch to the game that I like.

MELEE: Melee is actually insanely fun. Being able to tank and attack many enemies at once and enjoying the carnage you cause makes this game very positive. The problem however, is that most boss fights are IMPOSSIBLE to beat by melee only. You are forced into a position of using your gun for half the fights to do either gimmick bosses, or flying bosses. This is horrible since a good portion of equipment is focused around melee and doing different effects with charged attacks. You can only really play true melee in multiplayer where you are target dummy while your friends kill the boss.

ECONOMY: Scrap is much less plentiful, relying on selling random things you forget are in your inventory. Leveling up a gun to max isn't too painful, if you don't mind having a 50% scrap increase necklace on the whole game (if you find it). You need scrap for literally everything to level it up and by 30+ hours I have not leveled up more than a few weapons to max. The downgrading is a very good feature but It really should award you all the scrap you used. I don't mind losing materials to downgrading, but the scrap loss makes me hesitate and decide on whether its worth it.

ARCHETYPES: The archetypes should be able to be found a lot easier so you can experiment more early on. They are objectively the best part in the game and the skills are really great. Having to unlock them is tedious. I never found more than the starting classes in the whole game, because the other ones you have to find some hidden randomized points in the game to even unlock them.

MAP: The 3D map would be good if I didn't have huge areas that block out the whole mini-map. The maps are so winding and have so many directions I get lost in them easily and have had to backtrack more times than I'd like to count to try to fill it out and then find the normal way back.

WORLDS: The puzzles in these worlds are awful. I hated doing the water harp and the clockwork puzzle. Some of these items I don't understand how I would find naturally. Losomn is a decent area that doesn't make me too angry to go through. N'Erud is a awful wasteland that makes me dread walking through the massive area to try to find dungeons. Yaesha is not nearly as fun as it used to be, being a twisting path of branches and random drops to your death. The skyboxes for every map are very good though, and the art design is what carries the game.

ENEMIES: Every enemy in the game is not too bad. The elite enemies will ignore most of your damage and proceed to just beat you over and over and not stagger at all. Meanwhile, their attacks will stagger you almost every hit. I have been stun-locked to death many times from just one enemy or boss. In the first game you could put on heavy armor to mitigate it, now you have to use special rings and skills to fix it, which you may not find easily unless you look them up in the wiki, or level a prism to 50, which I still have not done.

Overall, the game runs decently well, but not all the time. I've had several instances of changing my archetype that have caused my computer to freeze.

Things I truly hated: Not being able to melee every boss. If you're gonna add melee rings, amulets, and mutators, let me melee every boss. Being stun-locked by enemies that I can one-shot. Having to do horrible puzzles when I just want to shoot things. There's like 4 items for every decision you make, how am I supposed to reliably do them when I have to take at least 30 minutes to search the whole map and then the place I want doesn't spawn? Why are half the rings in the game utterly worthless? Why does the 3 boss rush not give me a single item?
